First, we need to establish who Sojourner Truth is. She was an African American woman who was born into slavery in New York in the late 1700s. She became a famous abolitionist and women's rights activist in the mid-1800s, known for her powerful speeches and writings.

Next, we need to examine the Washington Monument. This is a large obelisk-shaped monument located in Washington D.C., built to honor the first President of the United States, George Washington. It was completed in 1884, several years after Sojourner Truth's death.

Now, we can ask ourselves: would Sojourner Truth have had the opportunity to use an elevator in the Washington Monument during her lifetime? The answer is no. The monument did not have an elevator until much later, in 1889, when a steam-powered elevator was installed. Sojourner Truth died in 1883, before the elevator was added.

Therefore, the answer to the question is (B) no, Sojourner Truth did not use the elevator at the Washington Monument, as it was not yet built during her lifetime.

The elevator was not installed until 1889, several years after Sojourner Truth had passed away. In fact, during the time the monument was being built, visitors had to climb stairs to get to the top.

3. Is there any record of Sojourner Truth visiting the Washington Monument while it was under construction? This one is harder to answer definitively, but as far as we know, there is no record of Sojourner Truth visiting the unfinished monument. 

So, based on the evidence we have, it is safe to say that Sojourner Truth did not use the elevator at the Washington Monument.
